After stating that many attacks go through walls they replied that attacks are suppósed to go through windows. Are you guys even reading my e-mails?

Pretty much everybody who has ever played this game disagrees with the statement that this game is completed. I guess they just confirmed that they took our money and then ran off.
Do not support these developers!

reviewText:
I'd like to start off by saying that I got this on Humble Bundle so I'm not exactly fussing over the fact that I 'bought' this game. It's still not an impressive game to me.

Wow, I played two hours and I think I got all I need to say and there's not even much to say about it. I don't have anything to really say that's positive about this game other than the idea. You're a group of survivors and you need to survive. There are different gamemodes and from what I remember there is survival, campaign(you start with 2 survivors, need to find more, you can secure 'nodes' (locations) across the map and it ties into the repetitive nature of the game and you also have objective locations you need to make your way to), and two others. They weren't very rememberable. Your nodes can also be attacked but I didn't care for the game enough to actually let it happen). The nodes themselves in the campaign mode act as 'checkpoint' spots that you can backtravel to when you fail a mission and you have spare survivors or if you finish a mission.

The gameplay is extremely flawed with very bad movement controls (click to move squad and  click + hold to designate facing direction for EVERYONE which makes it useless because why the would you want everyone to face in the same direction while you're getting beat up from behind and to the sides). Your squad lacks peripheral vision. The movement itself is held down by a part of the combat that is missing but I'll get to that. There's also these 'hearts' that constantly attract more and more zombies but there's also alarms that do the same thing and from what I could tell, the effects *STACK*. The alarms are only worse than the hearts because the power buttons are almost always on the other side of the entrances to the building but, then again... Some hearts are ominously locked inside a shed that require you to search the house for a code / button amongst the 20-something lootable items all the while getting hit wave after wave of annoying zombies.

When a squad member is attacked, it takes about a second for him to react, turn around / face the zombie, and then another 1-2 seconds to actually fight back. The melee is pretty random since even if your survivor is facing an enemy, he doesn't always react immedietally. I don't know if they decided to wank off because they get off to zombies or if they had a brain fart but my character with the axe kept on getting hit first when he should've been able to just chop the brain-dead(literally) zombie away with his weapon. Pistols also have a VERY low range (6 IIRC but another you get has 8, still extremely low) and make it extremely hard to keep range when there's even 3 zombies coming towards you. The zombies also move pretty fast when *not running*, so think on that. If you get a 'horde' after you, chances are you're going to get beat up pretty bad. Now, the thing that annoyed me the most is that there is NO AUTO ATTACK WHILE MOVING. This may seem stupid but attacking something while moving would be entirely realistic and even then this is a video game and the way the gameplay has been built up makes it seem like it would be crucial and yet it's not there. It's like playing a game where you can only shoot when not moving but the enemies move faster than you so you have to stop moving to attack them but you react very slowly, turn around slowly and the enemies keep coming non-stop. Oh, yeah, and you're short-sighted. Overall, the actual gameplay movement is slow and badly done. If your squad could act faster, not be stupid then I'd be kind of fine with it.

The special zombies I saw so far pretty much mimic the L4D Spitter / hunters but there's more ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t tacked onto them. The spitter gives no chance to avoid the acid since it's pretty much an immediate effect. The hunter or 'jumper' does as the name implies. It jumps *at* a survivor. No, it doesn't knock him down. It... Hits him. Fast. Or something. I don't know since the animation looks barely any different from any of the other zombies. The worst part is that, again, the effect is immediate. He pretty much teleports to your survivors and he takes a huge chunk of health in a few seconds which mixed with the combat and movement controls makes it pointless to even try to save the survivor (health items are costly to make and rare to find. You're lucky to even find a bandage. I maybe got 3-5 in 10 maps total which is only 60-100 HP for 4 squad members (20 per bandage)). There's also beefier zombies but honestly they only make the fast speed of the zombies and overall stupid intelligence of the AI seem worse than they really are. I got these beefy 'big' zombies pretty early in all of my attempts and I wouldn't be wrong to say they make hordes of zombies extremely unfair and unfun to fight.

The resource management is pretty neat but honestly it starts to demand a lot as you go on, granted it depends on the size of the node you try to secure or the amount of survivors that you have. For me, I rarely found extra survivors. I was lucky to find even one. I went through 2 large nodes and found a total of *ZERO* survivors, so there's that for you. Now, scrap and wood are rare/excessively common depending on, what I assume to be, RNG(random number generator). Each survivor can carry 6 slots (some items take up 2, a few such as food crates or gas cans take up 4)of items but you can find at least one blueprint for a medium backpack but it takes a lot to even make one. In the end, you will find it VERY repetitive to loot items. When you finish a level, any items on the ground or lootable objects not looted are removed / not lootable on return. It really ♥♥♥♥s the whole experience up especially since you can't loot everything so you have to leave some for the magical zombie genies to steal your discarded crap.

Overall, I'd say this game has a good idea but play a few hours and you might just realize how flawed this game is. Usually I'd be able to persevere but this game enraged me with how unfair and annoying it is that I had to take a breather and just uninstall it. It's unfair, it's not fun at all and the difficulty is centered around bad controls and bad balancing issues. Perhaps I'm just bad at it but I was doing pretty well until I got to the point of mass-spawning of enemies and the inevitable succumbing to the horrible controls.

5/10. It's okay.

reviewText:
Survivor squad is a tactical  overhead RTS that focuses on survival in a zombie apocalypse/outbreak. Players must take control of the survivors and scavenge for food, gas, and supplies whilst managing inventory space and surviving hordes of the flesh eating dead.

There are four modes of play. Multiplayer, where you pick a side of the zombie apocalypse, Humans or zombies. Death Lab, where you have to fight through hordes with a timer and make it to the decon chamber of the next lab. Survival, where you generally just try to survive the apocalypse itself. And finally, Campaign mode, which follows a storyline with unique events and a conclusion.
The game itself is incredibly hard and sometimes it isnt fun, but it keeps drawing you back in. The campaign starts out in an empty hospital with the player waking up from an induced coma. You take control of the randomly generated character and wander through the halls until you hear a growling noise, and are pounced upon by one of the dead. A man shoots the undead creature, and you stand up, bewildered and scared. The man explains what happened, in a typical zombie scenario style script, and the two of you go on your merry way.

Wait, havent we seen this before? Oh yeah, like in every single zombie themed  movie or television series-Im looking at you, The Walking Dead.  The whole zombie apocalypse thing is getting rather old to the point where this all seems rather repetitive and all the movies, games, and books just kind of glue together into some ominous pulsing conglomerate of gray mediocrity. Im not sure whether to poke it with a stick like a small child, or to ignore it all together. Since we've obviously decided to do the first option, Let me just state that Survivor Squad isnt that good. It isnt bad, but it isnt GOOD. It's OKAY. A lot of games are okay, but this one just strikes me as mediocre and uncreative. And boring. The game itself is a solid thing, like an idiot, but that doesnt make it good. reviewText:
I actually really enjoy this game despite it being VERY hard at times and a little buggy.
The game can go from being easy as pie in one moment, to almost impossible at the next but I find that keeps it exciting.
Rather than being able to rush through the game, you have to think, pace yourself and plan which many games now don't seem to do.
There are different game modes too, depending on how you want to play and the random generation make the game highly replayable.

My few gripes are firstly -  the mulitplayer. There was such potential for it and so many ways it could be handled and instead it's ended up being a 1 v 1 type thing.
Also, the game has it's fair share of bugs, which I found bearable (the game autosaves before each node) but many people seem to be pretty annoyed by them so if you're looking for a bug-free experiecne this may not be the game for you (but neither will Skyrim or Fallout).
But for the price of the game you cannot complain. I got my money worth at least three times over (I own it on Desura too).
If you enjoy randomly generated games that can get hard but are incredibly addictive then this is for you.

reviewText:
Take control of a team of four of the most generically named idiots as they fight for what's left of Earth, which consists entirely of the same 5-6 buildings in various random configuration.  Experience the thrill of puzzling out unexplained game mechanics, extreme jumps in difficulty, mashing the spacebar every 20 seconds to pause the game, figure out what just happened and micromanage your squad so hard you'll be telling them when to inhale and when to exhale.  Survivors so smart you'll have to tell them when to stop moving so that they can shoot the zombie that just appeared in front of them.  Attack move?  So 90s!  Get with the program!

Use a variety of six guns and four (inlcuding punching) melee weapons, each of which is utterly outclassed by the next upgrade.  If you hate difficult choices, you're in luck, as there's no reason to use an obsolete weapon ever!  They also look dinsticntly different in your character's hands. 2014 technology ladies and gentlemen!

Fight challenging zombies and special infected that Are Totally Not From Left 4 Dead 1 or 2.  There's the smo--grabber, the hunt--jumper, the boo--carrier, the spi-- oh it's actually called the spitter.

And the gadgets!  I'm very confident there were more gadgets asides from sentry guns, a futuristic area of effect bomb that kills all enemies nearby and video cameras to spot for the sentry guns, but I'll be darned if I can remember them.  There are also several suits of armour in the game.  With the same nuance you'dexpect by now they are linear upgrades with no drawbacks, entirely devoid of interesting decisions to make.

When it comes to character progression, the power is yours!  Experiment away as you can reset your perks at any time between missions.  Watch early perks be outclassed in utility by later ones.  Quickly settle in to your favourite character build and get busy wearing in that rut.

That someone possibly got paid actual money to draw the portraits in this game is unbelievable!  The portrait art is priceless, in the same way a three year old drawing on the wall in pastel excrement is priceless.  It is genuinely offensively horrible, like all the great works of deviantART.  Soldiers are assembled from bits of one another with differening skin tones and some will have helmets.  All have the same terrifying eyes that you will burn clear through your soul.

The campaign story line is incredible.  Writing on par with George R. R. Martin of Game of Thrones takes you on an epic journey where you will bump into a stranger who will tell you what to do.  And do it you will!  After you've done that, you'll find another man to tell you what to do!  And once you've done that, you'll kill a very fat zombie in a glass cage and the game will end with a credits screen.  A moving tale of redemption and the power of love.  The story is told in a very minimilist fashion which adds to the pathos and dark tones.  Feel your spine tingle with dread as unskippable slow text uncurls on the screen voiced by chipmunks very excited to see one another.  Creepy!

And if you want a change from the monotony of doing the same thing over and over again for too long, switch to Survival mode!  It's almost the same as camaign mode, but stripped down of what few choices you had about where to go next and what to defend!  You will go on a one way journey from random map to random map.

Where the game might possibly be worth a single dollar is in Death Labs mode.  With a limited budget you will assemble a squad of four, picking your weapons, ammo, gadgets and perks.  You start in a lab which resembles a maze strung out between elevators without any scientific research equipment to be seen.  Your goal is to get to the next level of the lab before an ominous decontamination timer reaches zero.  Such tension!  Don't remember that you can pause, hold down shift and scroll around to see items on the ground.  And certainly don't realize that every down elevator has a medkit in it.

Enjoy the utter crap shoot that is lab level 10 on this game mode.  Watch helplessly as a survivor will get pulled away from your group by a grabber, another, another, and then possible another.  All the while being pummeled by every zombie in the tight, tight corridor.

Get this game if you hate your money and you hate yourself!

P.S. ammo is unlimited.  You will always have a full reload.  At no time does the game tell you this.  I wiped on two campaigns before I realized I hadn't scavanged up any ammo as there literally wasn't any.  I guess that's my fault for heavily associating zombie apocalypse survival games with limited ammo.

(P.P.S the fat zombie in a cage is telekentically secreting eggs across the land which are hatching into these zombies.  That is the actual story line.  I am not making this up.  Apparently the eggheads in the lab captured it in their lab, somehow, at the start of the outbreak but before they realised it could just plant zombie eggs anywhere it wanted.)

reviewText:
Survivor Squad is a fun tactical game with one of the most sought after genres on the market right now... Zombies!

The controls are very simple and intuitive, altho it took me a little while to get used to right clicking the mouse to move my characters. Even tho it gets a little tight in situations, like when I forget to right click, and end up un-hi-liting my character. My fingers also tend to get confused, which leads to hitting the wrong numeric key, and sending the wrong soldier in the wrong way.

This game requires some series micro-management of your team if you want to keep everyone alive. This includes setting a rear guard at times, and especially individual movement of characters. Moving everyone all together will leave your defences wide open, as the survivors will not stop and attack enemies until they have completed their movement. So by individually moving them, it allows the stationary characters a chance to provide covering fire for those in transit.

This game is def worth the buy. It is a fine mixture of some of the finest genres going on right now. Tactics, zombies, looting, survival, gun fights, and procedural generation are all to be found in this game.

reviewText:
This game has a lot of potential and could be something better.
The characters that you control are just too stupid to allow me to reliably clear out buildings without taking too much damage. They will keep going to where you told them to go no matter what is in the way and wont attack and of the zombies hanging off of them. This means that there is a MASSIVE difficulty spike when you get to the level 2 buildings.
The special zombies are an alright idea but are just taken from Left 4 Dead so they don’t seem fresh and are just run-of-the-mill.
The spitters are just over powered as they can shoot through walls and any other obstacle. This means that you could be in a building and then there is spitter goo flying through 4 walls and 3 rooms to land directly on one of my team members.
The jumpers are basically hunters from L4D so they are as you can expect and mean that splitting up your squad is a bad idea in most situations. This offers a glimmer of hope to an otherwise frustrating game.
The crafting is a good idea because it makes you go back to old locations to gather resources that you had missed before. It also means that you can equip your team with better equipment so that they won't die so fast. You do, however, use cloth to make armour. You also use cloth to make bandages. Because of the stupidity of your squad members, you will be making bandages more than you will be making armour.
You also have to defend locations if you leave them for too long. I find that this is a good idea because it keeps you on your toes and makes you clear out the areas adjacent. This does mean that your squad will be really badly damaged or killed. This is because they throw hundreds if zombies at you and this is very difficult unless you have built defences to help.
Overall this game could be a great game if the problems are either tweaked or sorted out.

reviewText:
Survivor Squad is a fun little game - I understand it's based off a Flash game of the same name, although I must admit I've never played it.

Screenshots and videos might lead you to think it's less tactical than it actually is - careful positioning of team members is essential once you start to get onto the harder difficulties, as it gets pretty unforgiving, but there's enough variety in maps and looting to keep you going for quite a while.

It's not all great - there's a few annoyances, and the 'heart' levels which require you to destroy a 'heart' to stop infinitely spawning zombies quickly get tiresome. It would have been nice to see some 'special' zombie types that weren't literally just ripped from Left 4 Dead too, as much to show that there had at least been some kind of original thought gone into it.

All in all, it's probably about right for its price - it's an enjoyable little time-killer, but most people will probably only get 10 or so hours out of it before they get bored.

reviewText:
ITs a very enjoyable yet simple game. The game includes crafting, squad management, and zombie killing. The main question is pretty simple, just follow the red arrows to find the labs and kill the source. Controlling large cities is important as they generate resources.

When rescuing cities, visit the different houses and kill all zombies without activating alarms or spotlights that attract more zombies. Turrets are awesome. Important details to be aware is that you have unlimited ammo, that all fights happen at night, and that cities are randomly generated. If you lose a large city and you reclaim it, the resources it provides change. Secure cities by keeping 3 to 4 guys in it.

The game could use better survivor backgrounds and faces. The faces all look child-like. While there are characters of various races they are all guys. It seems that while some survive the zombie apocalypse, there are no women. The survival mode and death lab mode add additional depth to the game. Cheap and fun game. Worth the price, especially when its on sale.

reviewText: I play tactical games like Arma, xcom, and fallout 2. I find this game allows me to utilize tactics I've studied, such as bounding leap-frog movements or how to properly clear a building. There's a lot of strategy involved in every step you take, as well as which sacrifices you will make (what items to bring home, what nodes to capture, etc.). Very fun game, very simple, very cheap. A few minor glitches but they are overwhelmingly outnumbered by the positive qualities, much like you will be if you make a wrong move. HARDCORE: if you lose a squad mate then he's dead. You have to level up your guys and pick a few simple perks from a static perk tree that help define the roles in your squad. You take over nodes to gain resources and you have to manage and defend them by keeping recruits there and keeping them fed. This game is stressful, and makes you worry about your guys and each step you take. Very fun, highly addictive. Worth the money, especially for tactical lovers.

reviewText:
I really like the game play, a combination node-crawl / tactical RTS.  I really like the concept as well, crawling your way through a zombie infested city and managing your left-for-dead style squad at every turn.

But this game is broken and unwinable.

I've tried to win twice.  On my first play, I got in a scenario where I could not take and hold a node because it would get immediately recaptured by the zombies in the time it took for my guys to return from base after capturing (a return which was mandatory).  On my second play, I wisely set up a defensive ring so that I wouldn't have to deal with this.  Then, I got stuck in an Endless Loop of defending nodes, because the time it takes to defend on node was enough for another to get attacked.

Devs, I like your gameplay, but this is ridiculous.  There's no reason I should get game-breaking bugs on my first two playthroughs.  Do some playtesting next time.

The idea of a 4-man squad tactical game is great and the gameplay is good, but sometimes you get shafted and there's nothing you can do about it.

Pros: Good tactical play, resource management, and it gives the feeling that every move you make counts.

Cons: You can't choose whether or not to accept new survivors (which strain your food resources), once you stand next to them they join you. Sometimes, you will get a combination of random events that will kill your team and you cannot load a save file to recover them. That may leave you with a single survivor, in which case you pretty much lose the game.
